_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:    Central Missouri AGRIService, LLC. - Slater
Location:    227 Industrial Blvd, Slater, Mo.
Contact:     Tedd Wiseman    
Phone:         660-529-3419


1. The Facility Policy

Central Missouri AGRIService, LLC. and the employees of the Central Missouri AGRIService, LLC. in Slater are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Slater Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of bulk dry and liquid fertilizer and anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient. The facility also handles pesticides products.

The facility has (5) 30,000 gallon storage tanks and the largest tank onsite would be a railroad tank car containing approximately 160,000 pounds. There may be occasions where multiple railroad tank cars would be located at the facility. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a railroad tank car holding approximately 160,000 pounds. The facility also has (59) 1,000 gallon nurse tanks, (10) 1,450 gallon nurse tanks, (3) 560 gallon applicator tanks, (2) 400 gallon applicator tanks and (1) 335 gallon applicator tank for product distribution.  

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1," published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". The facility will work to meet the newest codes as time and budgets allow.

4. The Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releas

es of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. The Emergency Response Program.

The facility has;

    a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

    b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency planning and community 
        right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

    c. a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 
        1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are improvements currently being made to meet the newest ANSI Code.


    04/14/2011
